conclusion: To find the magnitude of the induced electromotive force (EMF) in the coil, we can use Faraday's Law of Electromagnetic Induction.
The induced EMF in a rotating coil in a uniform magnetic field is given by: \( \mathcal{E} = n \cdot B \cdot A \cdot \omega \cdot \sin(\omega t) \)
Where: \( n \) is the number of turns of the coil, \( B \) is the magnetic induction intensity, \( A \) is the area of the coil, \( \omega \) is the angular velocity, \( t \) is the time.
Since timing starts when the coil is in the neutral plane, at \( t = 0 \), the sine term \( \sin(\omega t) \) is zero.
We are interested in the maximum induced EMF, which occurs when \( \sin(\omega t) = 1 \).
Calculate the area \( A \) of the coil: \( A = l_{AB} \times l_{BC} = 0.2\, \text{m} \times 0.5\, \text{m} = 0.1\, \text{m}^2 \).

premise: Substitute the given values into the formula for the maximum induced EMF: \( n = 100 \), \( B = 0.1 \mathrm{T} \), \( A = 0.1 \mathrm{m}^2 \), \( \omega = 100\pi \mathrm{rad/s} \).
